story_txt:
2 draft novels, 15ish poems, a couple of blogs, and 5-6 short stories later, I consider myself a writer. An unpublished writer, sure, but a writer nonetheless. 
At this point in my career, I want the satisfaction of seeing my words on paper in a book that I can hand out to my friends and can sell. But while I wait to be discovered, I cannot help but take things in my own hands and put my own work out there by publishing the damn thing myself. Guess it's the Scorpio in me! 
I've tried sitting down and writing butt in chair every day. But I need a fierce goal. I need to know that there will be something tangible at the end of the road. I figured that if I did not have worry about the "if" or "when" of publishing a novel, I can just focus on writing and editing the novel. 
TELL US MORE ABOUT THE NOVEL!
Right. So there's this ongoing joke with my friends that started when I began to live in one of the most "interestingly ghetto" neighborhoods of Montreal, Côte-des-Neiges. Strange things have happened to me here. Very strange people live here. In fact, I was even compelled to sleep on friends' couches for a little while because the thought of crawling back to my dingy hole was the last thing I wanted to do after a night out. Thus the bum chronicles began! 
My friends often tell me I should write about those crazy city-life stories. So I thought I would inspire myself from those experiences and write a Trainspotting-like novel.
We are all like flies trying to find any scrap of life to hang onto only to buzz around the same pile of shit as everyone else. And then we are shooed away and smacked across the room face and butt flat against the wall. Or we just keep flying until our wings can no longer carry the useless burden of flapping and flapping about.
 



That's where you come in! I took a long look at how much it would cost to self-publish and self-advertise my own book. And if I could raise at least $5,000, I'll be off to a really good start while I finish writing my novel and get it ready to be published. I am even going to try to coincide being done with the book at the same time as this fundraising campaign ends. Crazy? Yeah, I guess that's one way to describe how I attack personal projects.
Here's the rough breakdown:
Self-Publishing Package 4 000,00 $ Extra Writing/Editing/Publishing Fees 900,00 $ Costco boxes of ramen noodles to survive on for at least 3 months 100,00 $ 150-book order to pimp out in the streets like a literate hooker 4 000,00 $ Amazing Book Launch Party 1 000,00 $TOTAL 10 000,00 $
I know I set my goal to $5,000, but hopefully together we'll be able to raise even more!

For sure for sure for sure, anyone who donates gets their name printed on a special thank you page in my book. On the right-hand side, you will find even more interesting perks such as thank you cards, a poem, a short story, and more! Plus, it would be interesting if many of you order the poems or the short stories, because they could be a part of another self-publishing project! The Bum Poems. The Bum Short Stories.
My perks range from $5 - $1000, but every dollar helps.
CHALLENGE ME!



There are many ways to support my weird writing need:
- Back my campaign today with your dollars, and claim your rewards!- Share my campaign with friends and family on Twitter, Facebook, websites, blogs, etc.- Interview me for your blog or website!- Come to my book launch and buy my book on-site- Put me in contact with anyone you may know in the publishing industry that could help me with advices, tips or whatnot.

story:
Hello!

My name is Fabio Periera and I'm trying to publish two non-fiction books as well as a collection of short stories and I'm looking for your help!

The first book is an as of yet untitled collection of short stories that I've accumulated over my travels and work experience. They touch on LGBT life, class and social mobility, dating and relationships, and family life.

The second is a non-fiction book on technology, media and American politics in the social media age.

My goal is to raise the money to edit (read: hire an editor) and publish a limited edition run of each of my two books, replete with beautiful art and paper. I will also release both books through digital publishers like Amazon, etc. I guess you could say that rather than just trying to write a book I am also trying to start a small independent publishing imprint too.

My writing has appeared on Rundown, Huffington Post, The Hollywood Reporter, New York Observer, Us Weekly.com, Style.com and on the homepages of many more publications. You can find my LinkedIn page here.

Thank you for supporting my campaign!

UPDATES

11 Jan - I've updated the incentives for the campaign. At the $20 level, it should also say that supporters receive both copies of both books in digital format and a thank you in the acknowledgements. IndieGogo doesn't let me edit the text field of perks after they've been claimed, which is fair enough really!

story:
Lisa Panepinto's debut poetry collection On This Borrowed Bike was just published by Three Rooms Press.  This indiegogo project is to raise funds for a book tour this spring and summer.

The Poems

“Simply complex and universally individual, Lisa Panepinto’s poems encompass politics and the soul, nature and the body, paradox and the mind. Panepinto’s voice is so assured and pure, so confident and directed, that to follow it on its intricate and profound journeys can bring serious joy. Far more ambitious than they might at first appear, influenced by Native American, beat, and experimental poetics alike, these are poems that do not shrink from the poet’s oldest task, the mighty healing work of the shaman.”
—Annie Finch, Among the Goddesses: An Epic Libretto in Seven Dreams


“Lisa Panepinto’s abstract and lyrical vignettes serve as a wonderful introduction to a fresh new voice, bound to rattle the canon.”

—Patricia Smith, Shoulda Been Jimi Savannah

“These minimalist and imagistic poems in Lisa Panepinto’s new collection of poetry are woven with the gossamer of crow dreams and water from endangered rivers. In these pages Justice falls in love with the blues. There’s scuffling and dancing, and it’s all coming down to what happens in the dark. There is enough love for everyone. Lisa Panepinto sings. You’ll want to be here.”

—Joy Harjo, She Had Some Horses

The tour

I'm hoping to do as many readings as possible throughout the US and Canada this spring and summer.  I like reading at bookstores, and am also open to reading at other places such as cafes, gardens, living rooms, libraries and schools.  

All monies from this indiegogo project, after costs, will be used for touring throughout the spring and summer. 

The author

I am a poet, radio host, essayist and editor.  I am author of on this borrowed bike (Three Rooms Press) and chapbook Island Dreams (Cabildo Press), and poetry editor for Cabildo Quarterly.  My writing has appeared in the Accompanist, Maine Peace Action Committee, Maintenant and on my blogs river pine anthology of civic discourse and who can be my emerson.  I hold degrees from Washington State University and the University of Southern Maine.

What I need help with and what you get

I will travel sustainably and frugally--on buses, trains, and bicycles, sleeping in tents and in couches whenever possible--but still need help with travel costs in order to do a book tour.  

Your generous contribution enables me to share my poetry with the world, and in return you will receive:

  • $5-9 - an mp3 audio file of me reading On This Borrowed Bike in its entirety, with guitar accompaniment, and a personalized thank you note
  • $10-19 - an audio file of me reading On This Borrowed Bike in its entirety, with guitar accompaniment plus the last five issues of Cabildo Quarterly, the literary broadside I help edit, my 2009 chapbook Island Dreams, and a personalized thank you note
  • $20-50 - a signed copy of On This Borrowed Bike, an audio copy of me reading the book with guitar accompaniment, the last five issues of Cabildo Quarterly, my 2009 Island Dreams chapbook, and a personalized thank you note
  • $51-above - a signed copy of On This Borrowed Bike, a copy of my chapbook Island Dreams, an audio version of On This Borrowed Bike, the last five issues of Cabildo Quarterly broadside, a personalized music compilation disc arranged by me, and a signed thank you note
  • $90 - Bookstore/Bookclub Special: Ten copies of 'On This Borrowed Bike' mailed to one location

Other Ways You Can Give

If you aren't able to make monetary contributions you can still assist this project by:

  • Helping me set up readings, interviews & reviews 
  • Telling others about the book & campaign, thank you!

story:
As many of you have heard, we in Brooklyn (and its surroundings) are beginning to solidify the Brooklyn Poetry Summit, which will be taking place the weekend of April 18th of the coming year with more than 20 readers from all over the country with poetics both disparate and in close conversation with one another. We are hoping to be able to bring our readers into town without them incurring financial burden, and to help mitigate the financial stress that so often roadblocks meetings of this sort.

The summit's goal is to provide a site for discourse, reading and listening whilst, of course, making similar provisions for partying with much vigor and refinement.   As we are doing our best to stay away from any institutional support while still being able to bring all these poets to town without financial burden, we need support from everyone, especially to adjust for relative distances and financial concerns of our readers .  So...donate, fast, furious, often, oftener...great "gifts," even better future payoff...think of this as your retirement fund. 



SCHEDULE:
